OOG.content: egological content discovers dimension of “we” as moment of the eidos “ego,” transcendental we not something other than transcendental Ego
OOG.linkedContent: egological content discovers dimension of “we” as moment of the eidos “ego,” transcendental we not something other than transcendental Ego

OOG.content: for Husserl, empathizing (Einfühling) possible due to apriori universal structures of sociality/historicity, external inquiry depends on internal intuition
OOG.linkedContent: for Husserl, empathizing (Einfühling) possible due to apriori universal structures of sociality/historicity, external inquiry depends on internal intuition

VM.content: Husserl’s alter-ego, nonviolent respect of secret, of separation, we can only know the other through analogical appresentation > translates recognition of radical separation
VM.linkedContent: Husserl’s alter-ego, nonviolent respect of secret, of separation, we can only know the other through analogical appresentation > translates recognition of radical separation

VM.content: for Husserl, my world is opening in which all experience occurs, including experience par excellence > transcendence toward Other as such
VM.linkedContent: for Husserl, my world is opening in which all experience occurs, including experience par excellence > transcendence toward Other as such

VM.content: Husserl called irreducible egoic essence of experience “archi-factuality” (Urtatsache)
VM.linkedContent: Husserl called irreducible egoic essence of experience “archi-factuality” (Urtatsache)

VP.content: for Husserl, the alter-ego in one’s interior solitude is only ever fiction
VP.linkedContent: for Husserl, the alter-ego in one’s interior solitude is only ever fiction

POOF.content: allied in “joint acquiescence to disjunction,” monadic alterities, the proper of the alter-ego is never accessible [see SPOM p. 35]
POOF.linkedContent: allied in “joint acquiescence to disjunction,” monadic alterities, the proper of the alter-ego is never accessible [see SPOM p. 35]

ATIA.content: Descartes’ argument is not that animals don’t resemble humans (they do!), it’s that we can’t make an interior analogy (judgment) based on exterior resemblance
ATIA.linkedContent: Descartes’ argument is not that animals don’t resemble humans (they do!), it’s that we can’t make an interior analogy (judgment) based on exterior resemblance

TN.content: for Husserl, when I touch myself w/ my finger: no haptical mirror-effect, no insinuation of alterity
TN.linkedContent: for Husserl, when I touch myself w/ my finger: no haptical mirror-effect, no insinuation of alterity

TN.content: Derrida defends Husserl’s stubborn conviction that we can’t know alter-ego, only through analogy, appresentation, that there’s an unbridgeable abyss (abîme infranchissable) > Husserl’s stance prevents risk of an immediate intutionism of the other
TN.linkedContent: Derrida defends Husserl’s stubborn conviction that we can’t know alter-ego, only through analogy, appresentation, that there’s an unbridgeable abyss (abîme infranchissable) > Husserl’s stance prevents risk of an immediate intutionism of the other

TN.content: pre-originary mourning (re: Husserl’s vigilant stance on alter-ego) tied to motif of exappropriation—interiorization, even introjection, never achieved [Derrida has more in common w/ Husserl than Merleau-Ponty?]
TN.linkedContent: pre-originary mourning (re: Husserl’s vigilant stance on alter-ego) tied to motif of exappropriation—interiorization, even introjection, never achieved [Derrida has more in common w/ Husserl than Merleau-Ponty?]

TN.content: the difference Derrida adds to Husserl’s alter-ego: recognize l’irréductible écart even in the touchant-touché de ma “propre” main [there’s alter-ego in my own proper body as human ego]
TN.linkedContent: the difference Derrida adds to Husserl’s alter-ego: recognize l’irréductible écart even in the touchant-touché de ma “propre” main [there’s alter-ego in my own proper body as human ego]

TN.content: Nancy: phenomenology touches/exceeds its own limit in Cartesian Meditations > “pré-donation of the alter-ego”
TN.linkedContent: Nancy: phenomenology touches/exceeds its own limit in Cartesian Meditations > “pré-donation of the alter-ego”

TN.content: intertwining btwn present/nonpresent ensures presence of alter-ego in heart of ego
TN.linkedContent: intertwining btwn present/nonpresent ensures presence of alter-ego in heart of ego

EW.content: even in the most marked transcendental idealism (Husserl’s), alter-ego leads back to a pre-egological and pre-subjectivist zone (transcendental passive genesis of time and other)
EW.linkedContent: even in the most marked transcendental idealism (Husserl’s), alter-ego leads back to a pre-egological and pre-subjectivist zone (transcendental passive genesis of time and other)

BSi.content: Celan’s tout autre [ganz Andere] not alter-ego, not another living present, but inaccessible other
BSi.linkedContent: Celan’s tout autre [ganz Andere] not alter-ego, not another living present, but inaccessible other

OG.content: Rousseau’s pity as distance, not “do onto others…” but “do good to yourself w/ as little evil as possible to others” > don’t interiorize other’s pain too much (it would no longer be the other’s)
OG.linkedContent: Rousseau’s pity as distance, not “do onto others…” but “do good to yourself w/ as little evil as possible to others” > don’t interiorize other’s pain too much (it would no longer be the other’s)
